Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 13, Section 10 on the Thirty-three Heavens

At that time, the heavenly multitudes gave rise to reverence and listened to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra's explanation of the essentials of the Dharma. They joined their palms above their heads and said to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra:

'We now see with our own eyes the power of this Dharma. The heavenly king's explanation of the Dharma accords with our minds and we attain pure faith. The messengers of Yama also gradually disappear. As soon as we hear the power of the Dharma explained by the TathÄgata, they all vanish. How much more so for those who cultivate it! If one cultivates it, one will reach the place of non-disappearance.'
At that time, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra gave rise to joy in his mind and said:
'I have accomplished what I set out to do.
I have done this in order to remove the heedlessness of these heedless gods, to make them attain heedfulness, and to bring them joy.

I will now explain the profound and wonderful Dharma for the sake of these heavenly beings, just as I heard the essential teachings of liberation from the Great Teacher in the past, contemplating the in-and-out breath, Ä€nÄpÄnasmá¹›ti.

I heard it in sequence from the ancient heavenly beings, and having heard it, I also saw the World-Honored One expound it for me. Therefore, I will now explain the mixed four noble truths for the heavenly beings, with four kinds of distinctions within one truth.

I will now explain it for the sake of all these heavenly beings, benefiting myself, benefiting others, and those sentient beings who transmigrate in birth and death, using various skillful means to explain the Dharma for them, causing the minds of sentient beings to become pure and mature.

I have thus explained the fifteen dharmas. I will now explain the sixteenth dharma for the sake of the heavenly beings, the dharma of the in-and-out breath, Ä€nÄpÄnasmá¹›ti, distinguishing the four noble truths with the characteristics of their own causes.
What is meant by explaining it in sequence?
This practitioner observes the bound mind-monkey of his own body.
The gods!
How does one bind the mind-monkey of thoughts and perceptions?
What kind of mind is bound?
It is the consciousness that is bound.
In this way, one observes the characteristics of the body with a single mind:

Observing the body according to the body, observing the defiled, undefiled, and neutral, observing the wholesome feelings according to the feelings, observing the painful, pleasant, and neutral feelings, observing the characteristics of the feelings themselves, observing the dharmas according to the dharmas, the wholesome, unwholesome, and neutral according to their own characteristics, this is called the four establishments of mindfulness.

This practitioner enters such dharmas, observes with a single mind all conditioned things, and observes the characteristics of the four establishments of mindfulness, which are the characteristics of the four noble truths.

In this way, the establishments of mindfulness pervade everywhere, namely the successive aspects, permanence and impermanence, combination and dispersion, emptiness and non-action, emptiness and non-self, destruction and decay.
Thus, contemplating suffering as impermanent, having seen the four establishments of mindfulness, one contemplates the self-characteristics of the four noble truths.
Contemplating them as they really are, one gives rise to the dharma of warmth, and from the dharma of warmth, one gives rise to wisdom.
It is like drilling for fire, first seeing the smoke, and then seeing the fire;
like drilling and rubbing, first producing hot air, and then fire.
Because of faith and joy, in all afflictions and ignorance, in the future, being able to give rise to the holy Dharma and Vinaya is also like this.
With the sixteen kinds, contemplate the four noble truths.
How does this dharma of warmth arise?
How does one contemplate the four noble truths?
Celestial sons!

Namely, this is the cause and condition of the noble truth of suffering, because of existence, it is impermanent, because of decay, it is suffering, because of separation from people, it is empty, and because of lack of self-control, it is non-self.
In this way, the four kinds of distinctions contemplate the noble truth of suffering.
The practitioner, having contemplated the noble truth of suffering, contemplates the noble truth of the accumulation [of suffering] with four kinds of discernment.
What are the discernments?

Namely, the continuation of conditioned forces, the flowing of similar fruits of accumulation through various existences, the flowing of all natures through existence, and the conditioned arising of existence through dissimilar continuations of power.
The practitioner further contemplates the noble truth of the cessation of suffering with four kinds of discernment.
Celestial sons!
How does the practitioner discern and cultivate the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

Because it abandons all afflictions, because it extinguishes the fire of afflictions and is free, because it is the supreme quiescence of all dharmas, and because it is the pure dharma that transcends birth and death.
The practitioner further contemplates the noble truth of the path with four kinds of discernment.
Celestial sons!
How does the practitioner discern and contemplate?

Namely, because it attains the stage of nonretrogression, because the path is nonerroneous, because it is the dharma abided in by all noble ones, and because it is the worldly-transcending dharma that cuts off and eliminates the afflictions of birth and death through unobstructed means.

These are the sixteen kinds of practices that I have explained. You heavenly beings should diligently cultivate and progress, observe the present warmth, and teach each other. From the in-and-out breath, the warmth arises, and from the warmth, the peak arises. With faith, focus the mind on the aggregate of merits of the Three Jewels and so forth, surpassing the previous contemplations.
'How does one contemplate and call it the peak path?
Like the peak on top of a mountain, the peak increases and grows, and one subsequently attains the wholesome roots of the acceptance of dharmas.
Because one attains acceptance, one abides in the third stage, called the arising of the present, not the acceptance of the present dharma.
Because of the acceptance of the present dharma, it is called the acceptance of dharmas.
Because acceptance increases, it is called the supreme worldly dharma.
In one moment, the mind and mental factors are called attaining the supreme worldly dharma.
Subsequently, one attains the stage of stream-entry.
Such a dharma, I have realized it myself.
If a person can realize such a Dharma, they will not see the terrifying messengers of Yama, nor will they be afraid.
Thus, all you celestial beings!
It is because of not being negligent that one attains such a Dharma.
Therefore, all you celestial beings should not be negligent.'
At that time, King Åšakra spoke a verse, saying:
If one can skillfully know the sixteen aspects of the in-and-out breath,
The dharmas of warmth and the peak, the dharma of patience, and the reverse and forward contemplations,
Knowing the supreme worldly dharmas, and subsequently knowing the truth,
Knowing the successive correct dharmas, and not losing the good path,
Liberating from the three bonds, and destroying the eight kinds of existence,
Daring to sever the evil paths, is therefore called a stream-enterer.
The defiled and unwholesome dharmas, definitely lead to the evil paths;
Flowing towards nirvÄá¹‡a, is therefore called a stream-enterer.
At that time, having spoken this verse, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, said to the assembly of devas:
'Thus, I have fully explained the sixteen kinds of mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation. You should contemplate them.
This path is tranquil and enters the city of nirvana, without any fear. It is cherished by all sages. Therefore, you should definitely practice this path.
If you fear the messengers of Yama, you should sequentially recollect these sixteen practices of inhalation and exhalation.
Furthermore, celestial sons!
There are seventeen kinds of intermediate existence. You should focus your thoughts and practice the path of tranquility.
If devas or humans contemplate this path, they will never fear harm from the messengers of Yama.
What are the seventeen kinds of intermediate existence?
It refers to seeing the characteristics at the time of death.
If one dies in the human realm and is reborn in the heavens, one sees joyful characteristics.
In the intermediate state, they see a white cloth, about to fall, fine, soft, and pure white. Seeing this, they are delighted and their complexion is cheerful.

When they are about to die, they also see a very delightful garden grove, lotus ponds that are also very delightful, rivers that are also delightful, and forests that are also delightful. They successively hear various singing, dancing, games, and laughter, and then smell various fragrances. All are loved and have an infinite number of fine textures combined.
In this way, they are successively reborn in the heavens, and due to their good karma, they immediately attain heavenly bliss.

Having attained this bliss, they smile and are delighted, their complexion is pure. Their relatives and siblings weep and wail, but due to their good signs, they do not hear or see, and their minds do not think of them.
Due to their good karma, when they are about to die, in the intermediate state, they greatly accomplish bliss.

First, they are born in a place of joy, with a heavenly body similar to the heavenly beings, similar to the heavenly multitudes. Such characteristics are similar to the place of birth, like a seal and what is sealed. Also, the appearance of all heavenly beings is similar, and they enjoy pleasures like the six heavens in the desire realm. Also, their activities and realms are similar, and their touch is also similar. The heavenly colors are similar.

Moreover, abiding in the intermediate state, seeing the excellent place of birth among the gods, one immediately gives rise to the mind to grasp and love the realm, and thus receives a heavenly body. This is called the intermediate existence in the beginning.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is the second intermediate existence?
If a person in JambudvÄ«pa ends their life and is born in Uttarakuru, they will see a fine, soft, red blanket with a lovely color.

Seeing it and being delighted, they give rise to a greedy mind and grasp it with their hands. Raising their hands to grasp it is like grasping empty space. Relatives call it grasping empty space with both hands.
Moreover, there is a wind that blows:
If this sick person is in the cold of winter, a warm wind blows, and if it is hot, a cool wind blows, removing the stuffiness and making the mind joyful.
Because of the mind's focus, they do not hear the sounds of sorrowful weeping and crying.
If their karma moves, their mind also moves, and they hear the sounds of crying and weeping. The karma wind blows them to be born in another place.
Therefore, when relatives and siblings are at the point of death, sorrowful weeping and crying are very obstructive.
If they are not obstructive, they are born in Uttarakuru.
In the middle, there are good signs that appear:
Seeing a pond of blue lotus flowers filled with geese, ducks, and mandarin ducks, surrounding and complete. The person sees it and immediately runs towards it.
In this way, in the middle, a good mind is born. When life ends, they immediately see a pond of blue lotus flowers and enter it to play.
If one wishes to enter the mother's womb in Uttarakuru, one emerges from the flower pond, walks on land, and sees the parents engaging in sexual union with desire.
Due to impurity, with inverted views, one sees one's father's body as a male goose and the mother as a female goose.
If one is to be born male, one sees one's own body as a male goose;
if one is to be born female, one sees one's own body as a female goose.
If one is to be born male, one feels aversion towards the father and lust for the mother.
Being born in Uttarakuru, this is called the second intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is the third intermediate existence?
If one dies in JambudvÄ«pa and is born in GodÄnÄ«ya, then there are signs that appear.
When one is about to die, one sees houses all turning yellow, like golden clouds covering everywhere.
Seeing yellow cloth in the sky, they raise their hands to grasp it. Relatives and siblings say the patient is grasping at empty space with both hands.
At this time, the person's good karma is about to end. They see their body as a cow and see herds of cows as they would in a dream.
If a man is to be reborn, he sees his parents' lustful union and impure conduct.
He sees himself as a human with many houses, and sees his father's form as a special bull, removing his father and uniting with his mother.
A man born in the land of GodÄnÄ«ya has such characteristics.
If a woman is born in the realm of GodÄnÄ«ya, she sees her own body as a lactating cow and thinks like this:
Why does the special bull unite with her and not with me?
After thinking like this, she receives a woman's body. This is called a woman being reborn in the country of GodÄnÄ«ya.
This is called the third intermediate existence.
Furthermore, devas and sons of the devas!
What is the fourth intermediate existence?
If a person in JambudvÄ«pa dies and is reborn in the realm of AparagodÄnÄ«ya, then signs appear.
They see a blue blanket, everything is blue, covering the entire sky.
They see their house as if it were empty space, fearing that the blue blanket will fall, they block it with their hands. Relatives and siblings say they are blocking the sky.

After death, they are born in the country of AparagodÄnÄ«ya. They see the intermediate existence body like a horse shape. They see their father as if he were a stallion, and their mother as if she were a mare, with the parents copulating with love and passion.
If a man is to be reborn, he thinks like this:
I should copulate with this mare.
If a woman is to be reborn, she sees her own body as if it were a mare's shape, and thinks like this:
Why does this stallion not copulate with me?
After thinking this, she immediately receives a female body.
This is called the fourth intermediate existence.
Furthermore, devas,
what is the fifth intermediate existence?
When the people of Uttarakuru are about to die, they see the following signs.
Devas,
if one has great deeds and a great mind, with the power of one's mind and deeds, one is reborn in the heavens.

When one is about to die, one reaches out with one's hand and grasps at space, like the mind in a dream. In the dream, one sees various beautiful flowers, and upon seeing them, one is delighted. One also smells the foremost, most wonderful fragrance, and the foremost, most exquisite colors are all fully endowed with the foremost adornments of blue, yellow, red, and white, and the foremost fragrance is in one's hand.
This person, upon seeing the flowers, gives rise to a greedy mind and thinks like this:
Now I see this tree, I shall ascend it.
Having had this thought, when one is about to die, one is born in the intermediate existence, and sees lotus flower trees of countless kinds, blue, yellow, red, and white.
One further thinks like this:
I shall ascend the tree.
Having had this thought, he then climbs a great tree, which is equivalent to ascending Mount Sumeru.
Having ascended this mountain, he sees the heavenly realm adorned with flowers and fruits, and thinks like this:
I should roam in such a place. I have now arrived at this place, where flower and fruit groves are everywhere.
This is called the lower rebirth of the people of Uttarakuru.
This is called the fifth intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is the sixth intermediate existence?
If the people of Uttarakuru, due to middling karma, are about to die and wish to be reborn in the heavens, then signs will appear.
When they are about to die, they see lotus ponds that are extremely delightful, adorned with many peaks, all fragrant.
Ascending this lotus, in an instant they fly through the air, as if in a dream.
When born in the heavens, they see wonderful lotus flowers, lovely and supreme, and think like this:
I should now go to the excellent lotus pond and pick these lotus flowers.
This is called the intermediate existence of the intermediate state of birth among the people of Uttarakuru.
This is called the sixth intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
What is the seventh intermediate existence?
Because of excellent karma, the people of Uttarakuru are born in the Heaven of the Thirty-three, in places such as the SudharmÄ Hall.
When they are about to die in Uttarakuru, they see an excellent hall, adorned with extraordinary beauty. At that time, the person ascends to the excellent hall.
In reality, it is not ascending to the hall, but ascending into space, to the heavenly realm.
Seeing the palace, they think of going there and are born in the hall as a heavenly son.
This is called the people of Uttarakuru who, after death, are born in the heavens, receiving a superior rebirth.
This is called the seventh intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
What is called the eighth intermediate existence?
When the people of Uttarakuru are about to die, then signs appear.
Heavenly sons!
They see the rows of gardens and groves, places for playing and frolicking, fragrant and delightful, hearing which they are delighted, not much suffering and distress.
Because of no suffering and distress, their minds are not turbid, with a pure mind they give up their lives and receive the body of the intermediate existence.
They see the heavenly palaces and have this thought:
I shall ascend to this palace and play.

Having had this thought, they immediately ascend to the palace, see the heavenly multitudes traveling through the sky, either running, staying, or in the midst of the mountain peaks, or touching each other's bodies, playing everywhere.
Dwelling in the intermediate existence, they see their own bodies ascending to the heavens as if in a dream.
The thirty-three heavens are supremely delightful, with all five desires fully present. They think like this:
I should now go to such a place.
Having had this thought, they are immediately born in the heavens, taking on existence due to causes and conditions, with superior, middling, and inferior levels of existence.
Having been born in the heavens, they see various excellent gardens and forests, longing to obtain them, and die in Uttarakuru, being reborn in these heavens.

In this way, all the people of Uttarakuru, having been reborn in these heavens, with the intention born from remaining karma, enjoy the pleasures of desire, greedy for the objects of the five desires, singing, dancing, playing, and experiencing the pleasures of love. They delight in roaming the mountain peaks, enjoying many pleasures, and love all desires.
Why is this?
Because of previous habits, the love of habits grows.
Thus, all you sons of gods!
This is called the people of Uttarakuru ending their lives and being reborn in the heavens. Having been born in these heavens, the signs of play and death due to habituation.
This is called the eighth intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly beings,
what is the ninth intermediate existence?
If a human of GodÄnÄ«ya dies and is reborn in the heavens, there are two kinds of karma.
What are the two?
First, remaining karma;
second, karma for rebirth.
When reborn in the heavens, how does that person experience intermediate existence?
When approaching death, there are signs that appear.
When the present retribution is about to end, or in intermediate existence, there are signs that appear, agitated like a dream.
Heavenly beings,
when a human of GodÄnÄ«ya is about to die, due to good karma, when about to give up life, the breath does not become turbid, the pulse does not break, and the faculties are pure.

At that time, in order, they see a great pool of water like vaiá¸Å«rya, entering the pool to cross over. The water is just right, neither cold nor hot, flowing and floating to the other shore. In this way, they approach the place of rebirth.
When they reach the other shore, they see heavenly maidens of the utmost beauty, adorned in various ways, playing, laughing, singing, and dancing.
Having seen this, the person's lustful mind draws near, and they embrace the woman. At that moment, they are born in the heavens, experiencing heavenly bliss.
Like a dream, the intermediate existence is instantly destroyed. With immeasurable confusion, they are born and immediately awaken, seeing wondrous forms and receiving a supreme, wondrous body.
This is called the ninth intermediate existence.

The birth of people in GodÄnÄ«ya has three gradesâ€”superior, middling, and inferiorâ€”but the same light, the same intermediate existence, the same views, and the same life practices. Everything is similar, unlike the three kinds of birth experiences of the people of Uttarakuru.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is called the tenth intermediate existence?
When the people of PÅ«rvavideha are about to die, they see the signs of death.

They may see the signs of their own karma or the karma of others, or they may see a magnificent palace with banners and canopies, adorned with railings. In the intermediate state, the mind gives rise to joy, and they roam around everywhere, wishing to approach rebirth.
Outside the palace, they see karmic similarities, seeing beautiful women singing and enjoying themselves with men, with the utmost adornments, singing, dancing, and laughing.
In the intermediate state, they think like this:
I should go out of the palace to see the beautiful women and men, and play, sing, dance, and laugh with them.
Why is that?
Because the beautiful women and men play, sing, dance, and laugh the most.
Having thought this, they immediately go out and enter the crowd to play.
At that time, the person knows for themselves that they have entered, just like waking up from sleep, and are immediately reborn in the heavens.
This is called the tenth intermediate state of existence.
This is called the intermediate state of existence in the four continents.
I know this subtle light of the intermediate existence, but others cannot understand it.
Even though it is a worldly phenomenon, no one can see it.
Furthermore, devas,
what is called the eleventh intermediate existence?

Those hungry ghosts who are born among hungry ghosts due to unwholesome karma, when their unwholesome karma is exhausted and they experience the remaining wholesome karma, the wholesome karma created in other realms, the delightful karma like parents, wishing to be born in the heavens, then there are signs that appear.
How is it that when existence is exhausted, the mental signs appear?
Devas,

if one dies among hungry ghosts and wishes to be born in the heavens, in the realm of hungry ghosts, hunger and thirst burn the body, jealousy destroys, always coveting food and drink, always thinking of beverages, only thinking of food and drink, nothing else is known.

When about to die, they no longer give rise to thoughts, and their original thoughts all cease. Their bodies are free from heat, soft, and cool. Their bodies grow long hair, and all the evil insects on their bodies fall off. Their complexions are pure, and cool breezes touch their bodies.
When approaching death, they are all free from hunger and thirst, and their faculties are pure.
Vultures, crows, and other evil beasts that always peck at their eyes all stay far away when they are about to die.

They see rivers of food and drink overflowing and filling up. Entering the intermediate state of existence, due to their previous habits, although they see food and drink, they do not drink or eat, only looking with their eyes, like a person in a dream who sees food but does not drink or eat;
or like eating in a dream, although eating they are not satisfied.
Thus, although they see it, they are not yet satisfied, only giving rise to joy.

Seeing the heavenly realm as delightful, like one who perceives form, the mind immediately gives rise to thoughts, rushing towards it, hoping to go to that place. Having thought, one immediately proceeds and is born in the heavenly realm.
This is called the eleventh intermediate existence.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is called the twelfth intermediate existence?
Due to delusion, one receives an animal body with various kinds, many causes of delusion,
and due to the ripening of karma, one experiences immeasurable hundreds of thousands of millions of birth and death bodies.
Due to the accomplishment of karma, one falls into hell, hungry ghosts, and animals, and the karma created over immeasurable eons revolves in the world, inexhaustible and inconceivable.
From beginningless time, one is crooked and does not benefit, harming beings and revolving endlessly.

Among the animal realm, there are countless species, countless types of food, countless paths, countless types of bodies, and countless types of minds. The seeds of these minds create countless karma. Either one does not believe and creates evil karma oneself, or one teaches others to do so.
When the retribution is exhausted, it is like a drop of water in the great ocean, causing the ocean to dry up.

In the ocean of karma, a drop of animal karma is exhausted. Due to other good karma, one dies in the animal realm and is reborn in the two heavens, either in the Heaven of the Four Heavenly Kings or in the Heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials.
When the suffering retribution of the animal realm is about to end, there are signs that appear. The signs that appear are of countless types and cannot be fully described.
Dying in the animal realm and being reborn in the heavens is extremely rare, not to mention in the realm of hungry ghosts or hell beings.
Why is this?

Due to their deluded minds, they create much evil karma and fall into the realm of animals. The evil karma created in one lifetime is not exhausted even after hundreds of thousands of lives, and they may transmigrate through birth and death for one kalpa up to hundreds of thousands of kalpas. Bound by the chains of karma, they wander in the world and receive the body of an animal.
Therefore, it is better to fall into hell or the realm of hungry ghosts than to receive the deluded body of an animal.
For this reason, it is extremely difficult for an animal to be reborn in the heavens after death, unlike in the hells.

Thus, when an animal is about to die in a place of suffering, it sees a light appear. Due to other good karma, its deluded mind becomes thinner and less, and its original wisdom slightly increases, with its mind gradually becoming sharper.
When it is about to die, it sees the appearance of light, such as seeing mountains and valleys, various trees and forests, various streams, various rivers and ponds, and seeing food and drink.

If one remembers seeing worldly knowledge, one sees a place of happiness, either in the mountains or in the forest, or remembers food and drink or sees a place of happiness, and immediately runs towards it. Like what is seen in a dream, one runs towards it. In this way, one approaches the place of rebirth.

One then receives a heavenly body, like waking from a dream, seeing various forms and colors, in hundreds of thousands of myriads of places of rebirth, all of which have never been seen before. Seeing this, one is delighted and gives rise to a rare mind.
What kind of thing is this?
How can there be this?
What causes are there for this?
Because of not being accustomed to it and because the consciousnesses are dull, therefore, one gives rise to a rare mind:
I should go there and completely take possession of this thing.
Because of other good karma, one gives rise to such a mind. For this cause and condition, one gives rise to such an intention. When one has this thought, one is immediately born in the heavens.
This is called the twelve intermediate existences. They are the most difficult, the most rare, and the most difficult to know.
Among the playful, karma is the foremost.
In various karmic realms, the great illusory mind plays in the realms of birth and death, playfully deceiving sentient beings.'
At that time, the devas, having heard what Indra said, gave rise to deep faith and spoke a verse, saying:
The Heavenly King is like a parent, benefiting the devas and the world,
The Heavenly King benefits us, in this world and the future.
He preaches the Dharma for us, cutting off the mind of heedlessness,
We will surely attain the path of nirvana that ends suffering.
Using the present karmic fruits and retributions, he proclaims for us,
Using the Dharma of birth and death, he shows the world to make them understand.
The Heavenly King sees the truth and benefits us,
Because of my foolishness, he showed me with wisdom.
With a greedy mind, loving court ladies, always seeking sensual pleasures,
The heavenly king showed us the causes and conditions of birth and death,
The king is like a guide for the blind, a great medicine for the sick,
Expounding the path of the true Dharma, benefiting the heavenly multitudes.
Since the heavenly king is like this, speaking the Dharma to benefit,
Causing the Yama prison guards to all be extinguished and no longer appear.
At that time, after the heavenly multitudes spoke this verse, the Heavenly Emperor Åšakra again told the heavenly sons:
What is called the thirteenth intermediate existence?
The sentient beings in the hells have rarely and with difficulty been born in the heavens.ğŸ”½Due to the remaining karmic causes and conditions and the causes and conditions of goodness,
As the karma matures, it is the utmost coolness and the utmost benefit.
First falling into hell, goodness serves as the condition for release. Having escaped from immeasurable suffering and distress, one is born in a place of immeasurable happiness and bliss.

The beings in hell are those in the hells of Reviving, Black Rope, Crushing, Screaming, Great Screaming, and Intense Heat, as well as the various chambers and places of great suffering, the most terrifying and hair-raising places, surrounded by blazing flames.
When the hell beings, due to the exhaustion of their karma, are about to be released from this hell, there will be signs that appear.
How does the intermediate existence give rise to rebirth in the heavens?
Due to the causes and conditions of karma, one abandons great suffering and experiences the utmost bliss.
Celestial sons!
When the life of a hell being is about to end due to the exhaustion of evil karma, if the jail guards throw them into a cauldron, they will be like water bubbles, extinguished and not reborn.
If struck with a stick, one dies immediately upon being struck and does not revive again.
If placed in an iron cauldron, one dies immediately upon being placed there and does not revive again.
If placed in a river of ashes, one dissolves upon entering and does not revive again.
If struck with an iron rod, one dies immediately upon being struck and does not revive again.ğŸ”½If eaten by iron-beaked birds or iron crows, one does not revive after being eaten.
If taken and eaten by various ferocious beasts such as lions, tigers, and wolves, one does not revive after being eaten.
When the evil karma of the hell beings is exhausted, after they die, they will no longer see the wardens of Yama.
Why is this?
Because they are not sentient beings, just as when the oil and wick are exhausted, there is no lamp. When karma is exhausted, one will no longer see the wardens of Yama.
Just as when the sunlight appears in JambudvÄ«pa, there is no darkness.
When evil karma is exhausted, the wardens of Yama are also like this.

The evil mouth and evil eyes, which resemble the appearance of sentient beings, and the terrifying forms all completely disappear, like breaking a painted wall, and the painting also disappears. The painted wall of evil karma is also like this. One no longer sees the terrifying forms of the Yama hell wardens.
Because the TathÄgata has said:
The Yama hell wardens are not sentient beings, therefore it is called hell.
Sentient beings escape from hell and are reborn in the heavens.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, spoke in verse, saying:
Just as a person who encounters an enemy, and escapes without any difficulty,
Just as obtaining many friends, all the benefits of skillful means.
Having escaped from the place of evil karma, and the powerful hell wardens,
Now, having attained good karma, one is born in the heavenly world.
When that person is born in the heavens, with immeasurable adornments,
Always enjoying heavenly pleasures, until their good karma is exhausted.
That person is not in control, when karma is exhausted, they fall back down,
Just like a lamp, when the oil and wick are exhausted, the light also goes out.
Blown by the wind of karma, falling down from above,
Turning due to the power of the wind, transmigrating in the world.
If a person has wisdom, they are not bound by karma,
Karma cannot bind them, they do not transmigrate in birth and death.
Like using the fibers of lotus roots, wanting to tie up Mount Sumeru,
That person crossing the wilderness, without worry or distress;
